text:
A federal judge in Texas has again 
struck down the DACA program.

And crews continue to search for bodies in 
Morocco after last Friday's deadly earthquake.

Good morning. I'm Nora Raum, with NPR 
News, and here are today's top stories:

A federal judge in Texas has again struck 
down a program that protects undocumented

immigrants brought to the U.S. illegally 
as children. From member station KERA,

Stella Chávez reports the latest 
ruling blocks efforts to codify the

policy known as DACA — Deferred 
Action for Childhood Arrivals.

"U.S. District Judge Andrew Hanen previously 
declared the DACA program unlawful two years

ago. His latest order is in response to 
a request from nine Republican-led states

to find the Biden administration's 
efforts illegal and end DACA. Hanen's

decision keeps deportation and work permit 
protections in place for the nearly 600,000

current DACA recipients, but new applications 
can't be processed. The Biden administration

is expected to appeal and the case will 
likely return to the U.S. Supreme Court.
"I'm Stella Chávez, in Dallas."

The Senate held a closed-door meeting yesterday 
to hear from the nation's big biggest technology

executives on artificial intelligence. Majority 
Leader Chuck Schumer had organized the conference,

saying everyone agreed the government 
has a role in the oversight of AI:

"Our work is just beginning — we 
need to have more of these forums,

and we need to get our committees working 
on different parts of legislation because,

again, to not act would be something 
that, something we want to avoid."

There apparently was no agreement yesterday 
on what government regulation would look like.

In Morocco, authorities say there is no hope of 
finding anyone else alive after last Friday's

earthquake. NPR's Eleanor Beardsley reports 
rescue crews are still searching for bodies:

"58-year-old Brahim Agoudahid weeps as 
he describes the wonderful life in his

village of Imi N'Tala before the earthquake. 
The indigenous Berber village perched in the

rocky Atlas Mountains got tourists from around the 
world. Now, Imi N'Tala is a scene of devastation

and wreckage after part of the mountain sheared 
off and crushed it. On this day, rescue teams

with dogs were able to extract a few bodies from 
the rubble after hours of digging. Within minutes,

they were placed back into the ground next to 
the ruined village as men prayed and women wept.
"Eleanor Beardsley, NPR News, Morocco."

Rescue teams in the Libyan city of Derna are 
searching for people still missing after a huge

flash flood Sunday night. The Associated Press 
reports at least 5,100 people have died and

thousands more are missing and feared dead as a 
result of Storm Daniel. Aid workers say the flood

destroyed the center of the densely populated 
city and that there are bodies everywhere.
You're listening to NPR News, from Washington.
